config.title: Mole self-assessment
config.intro_title: Could you have a cancerous mole?
config.intro_copy:
Skin cancer is one of the most common cancers in the UK but the good news is that if the signs and symptoms are spotted early it's easier to treat.

Use this test to find out whether you may have a mole that needs to be checked.

q.title: New question
q.body: Do you have a combination of fair skin, blue eyes and fair hair?

q.title: New question
q.body: Approximately how many moles do you have?

a.body: I have just a few moles

q.title: New question
q.body: Have you ever been severely sunburnt, with blistering and pain afterwards?

q.title: New question
q.body: Has a close family member ever had a cancerous mole?

q.title: New question
q.body: Do you have a mole with any of the following characteristics?

a.body: Larger than 4mm diameter or has got bigger
Changed colour, developed different colours or got darker
Changed shape or become irregular around the border
Has risen above the skin surface

q.title: New question
q.body: Does your mole bleed, itch, scale or ulcer?

a.body: Yes, I have two or more of these signs
Yes, I have one of these signs
No, I don't have any of these signs

q.title: New question
q.body: Do you have any large, irregular (atypical) moles?

a.body: Yes, I haveÂ 6 or more large irregular moles
No, I have no large irregular moles

q.title: New question
q.body: How often do you use sunbeds?

a.body: Often, at least once a week
Sometimes - once or twice a month
Rarely, less than once every six months
Never, but I have in the past

results.ri:
Based on your responses today it's unlikely you have a cancerous mole.

Skin cancer is becoming more common in this country, which is why it's important to be aware of your skin and regularly check your moles, both old and new.

The best prevention against skin cancer is:
  • Spend time in the shade when the sun is at its strongest - between 11am and 3pm in the UK
  • Make sure you never burn
  • Aim to cover up with a T-shirt, hat and sunglasses
  • Remember to take extra care with children
  • Then use factor 25-30 SPF sunscreen.
  • Remember, if you have any concerns or your moles change, tell your GP.

Based on your responses today you should have your moles checked by your GP or health professional.

They will ask you about any recent changes to your mole and when the changes started. They may also ask you about your family history to see how likely you are to be at risk of a cancerous mole.

The best prevention against skin cancer is:
  • Spend time in the shade when the sun is at its strongest - between 11am and 3pm in the UK
  • Make sure you never burn
  • Aim to cover up with a T-shirt, hat and sunglasses
  • Remember to take extra care with children
  • Then use factor 25-30 SPF sunscreen.

Based on your responses today you have a mole that needs to be checked by a GP or health professional, who will give you a proper examination and diagnosis.

They will ask you about any recent changes to your mole and when the changes started. They may also ask you about your family history to find out how likely you are to be at risk of a cancerous mole (malignant melanoma). 

The fact that your score is high does not necessarily mean that you have a nasty mole, merely that the mole should be examined.

And remember, the earlier a possible cancerous mole is checked, the easier it is to treat so see your GP as soon as possible.

link_items.ri: Real life: why routine checks are important

ib.title: Did you know?
ib.body:
Skin cancer is one of the most common types of cancer in the UK, and the number of people who develop skin cancer is increasing. According to Cancer Research UK, 12,800 people were diagnosed with malignant melanoma (a type of skin cancer) in 2010 in the UK.

Remember, some melanomas do not start in a mole so any new pigmented blemish should be examined.
ib.name: Did you know?

ib.title: Sunbeds and the law
ib.body:
In April 2011, it became illegal for under 18s to use sunbeds. The Sunbeds Regulation Act 2010 aims to protect under 18s in search of a year-round tan from putting their health at risk.

The Act means that under 18s cannot use tanning salons and sunbeds at premises including beauty salons, leisure centres, gyms & hotels.
ib.name: Sunbeds and the law
